screening_results.reason: fMRI study of face identity and eye-gaze perception — clearly social-related processing (social communication/perception of others), satisfying I1. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone), so include for full-text review to verify I2.

fMRI study measuring amygdala responses to racial ingroup vs outgroup faces, which is a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants identified as White or Black (healthy adults implied), but age range not reported; include for full-text to confirm I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining gaze direction effects on face processing—a social perception/communication task—so I1 is satisfied. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not reported in the abstract, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed without full text; therefore include for full-text review.

Functional MRI was used while healthy volunteers performed social tasks (empathy and forgivability judgments), directly addressing social-related processing. Although participant ages are not specified, the sample of 'ten volunteers' is consistent with adult healthy participants; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Event-related fMRI recorded while human subjects performed social judgments (trustworthiness of faces), clearly a social processing task. Participants are described as subjects (healthy adults implied) within typical adult age range. This meets inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract describes simultaneous fMRI during a social interaction (a deception game between pairs), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages 18–65, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

The study uses fMRI during attributional decision tasks probing self-related social cognition (self-responsibility, self-serving bias) and reports results in normal/healthy subjects. Thus it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI measuring neural responses to social/moral judgments of faces (meets I1). It does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status in abstract, so full text is needed to confirm I2; therefore include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in normal (healthy) subjects performing a social-related task (watching movie clips of social interactions), matching the review objective. No exclusion criteria apply. fMRI study examining neural responses to mutual vs. averted gaze—a social perception/communication task—reporting STS and FFG activations. Participants are described as 'subjects' with no clinical populations indicated, consistent with healthy adult sampling. Meets criteria for an fMRI social-task study and inclusion of healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social interactions (cooperation vs competition) involving monitoring others’ actions and social cognition, satisfying I1. Participants are human and described as 'individuals' (healthy adult sample implied), meeting I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment involving Theory of Mind/social cognition). Abstract reports 19 healthy participants, meeting inclusion requirements. Age range not specified in abstract — included for full-text review to confirm ages.

This is a narrative review of MRI findings in adolescent brain maturation, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets exclusion criterion E1 (systematic review/review article). The abstract does not report fMRI results in healthy adult participants.

The abstract describes two fMRI experiments on understanding intentions in social interactions—a social cognition task relevant to the review. While participant ages are not specified, the study appears to involve healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), using healthy normal subjects—meets I1. Abstract indicates ten right-handed normal subjects but does not report ages, so I2 (age 18–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review to verify age eligibility.

fMRI study where participants performed impression formation about other people, a clear social-cognitive task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Event-related fMRI in healthy participants examined processing of emotional (angry) voice prosody—a social communication task assessing perception/understanding of others. Fits social-related processing in adults. Abstract indicates healthy subjects; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind and empathy) in healthy human volunteers; meets I1. Participants described as healthy volunteers, but age range (18–65) not reported in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of I2.

fMRI study examining recognition of visual feedback as self- versus other-generated (perception/understanding of self/others), which is a social-related construct. fMRI study scanning participants during a face-perception/one-back task where affective person knowledge (social cognition) is spontaneously retrieved—meets social-related processing (I1). This fMRI study measured neural responses to faces and facial expressions (social perception of others), meeting I1. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicit healthy status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify I2.

The study used functional MRI to measure brain activity during kinship-related social scenarios evoking affiliative emotion, meeting I1 (social-related fMRI task). The abstract describes human participants with no indication of clinical populations, implying healthy adults, satisfying I2. No exclusion criteria apply.

Study used fMRI while mothers listened to infant cries probing attachment/affiliation-related social processing, meeting I1. Participants are adult mothers with no clinical groups mentioned, consistent with healthy adults (I2). Age ranges not explicit, so some uncertainty remains; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study investigating empathy/perspective taking (social cognition) in healthy adult participants (n=18). Task involves self/other perspective taking during pain perception, meeting social-processing construct; participants are healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text extraction and analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI during social-cognition tasks in neurologically normal participants, meeting the review objective. Age range (18–65) is not specified, so full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

fMRI study involving human participants processing emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), meeting I1. Sample consists of adolescents rather than adults (not within 18–65), and the fMRI task (Monetary Incentive Delay) is a monetary reward task rather than an explicitly social-related task. Therefore the study does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2 based on the abstract.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing social-cognitive processes (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) while participants performed action observation tasks under cognitive load, indicating a social-related task. Participants are human (presumably healthy adults) and no review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets I1 and I2.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of visual perspective selection, a social-cognition task (perspective taking). Although participant health/ages are not explicitly stated, this is a typical healthy adult cognitive neuroscience sample; include for full-text verification of demographics.

This fMRI study measured BOLD responses during action observation and execution after sensorimotor training pairing shapes with hand actions, addressing mirror responses relevant to perception/understanding of others (social processing). Human participants are reported; likely healthy adults. Satisfies criteria I1 and I2.

Abstract reports a combined fMRI and eye-tracking study of social cognition (interaction vs observation) in human participants, satisfying I1. No clinical groups or ages are specified but participants appear to be healthy adults and no disorders are mentioned, so I2 is likely met; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study manipulating sociality during a working memory (n-back) task in humans, satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

The study used fMRI to measure neural responses while healthy adult participants viewed others in pain (a social perception/understanding of others task). Participants were healthy adults (likely 18–65). This directly meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of person memory and recognition (familiar, famous, novel faces), which qualifies as social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). This fMRI study investigates perception of others' gender from facial cues, a social-perception task (meets I1). The abstract mentions participants but does not specify ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm I2 (healthy adults 18–65).

fMRI study explicitly examines neural responses during interpersonal resource conflicts (a social task). The abstract reports fMRI while participants performed tasks manipulating abstract vs. concrete mindsets, but it does not clearly state that tasks involved social-related processing nor report participant ages/health. Study used fMRI while participants judged attractiveness of other people (a social-related task — perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant ages or clinical status, so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm age 18–65 and health status.

Study used task-based fMRI to examine neural responses to social inclusion/exclusion (social processing) in human participants; meets age/group criterion implied (healthy adult participants). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments in which participants made mental-state (social-cognitive) judgments about individuals and groups, meeting I1. Participant ages/health status are not specified, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI to measure neural responses to real-world romantic interest/rejection (a social task involving perception and understanding of others) in participants who underwent scanning. fMRI study investigating communicative intentions and brain systems (mentalizing and mirror neuron) during social interaction tasks; likely healthy adult participants typical for such neuroimaging work. fMRI study in healthy adults (mean age 24) using a social task (hand-holding with friend vs stranger vs alone) that probes social regulation of threat-related neural responses. Meets I1 (social-related fMRI task) and I2 (healthy adult participants). No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was used while participants processed different types of laughter and attended to social information, addressing social communication/perception (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of communicative (social) gestures during observation and imitation, involving human participants (n=20). Directly addresses social communication (I1). Abstract reports training-related changes in neural activation and connectivity associated with altruistic behavior in healthy adults, indicating functional neuroimaging of social processing. fMRI study examining social-related processing (responses to outcomes for self, friend, antagonist) in healthy participants (N=31). fMRI was used while participants encoded and later propagated social messages, addressing social cognition/communication (mentalizing/reward systems). fMRI study of social-related processing (recognition of others' action 'vitality forms') satisfies I1. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18–65), so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; per instructions, include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind (social cognition) tasks comparing emotions, beliefs, and pain in 46 volunteers; involves healthy participants and social-related processing, meeting I1 and I2.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social-evaluative processing (self-conscious emotion) with neural responses reported (MPFC, striatum), addressing social-related processing. This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21 males) who performed a social-related task (rating naturalness of dyadic nonverbal interactions), addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract reports an fMRI study of impression formation (social cognition) in human participants; no indication of clinical populations. Fits social-related task with healthy adult participants; meets inclusion criteria for full review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using perception of biological motion (a social perception task) and includes adult participants; thus it meets I1 (fMRI during a social-related task) and I2 (includes healthy adults aged 18–65). No exclusion criteria apply.

This study used fMRI while healthy participants performed social-related tasks (eye-gaze detection, self-propelling motion, implicit mental-inference role-playing), addressing social perception and mentalizing. Participants are described as healthy (adult) subjects. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI was conducted during a third-party punishment task probing attribution of intentions and moral responsibility—social cognition. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Thus it meets both I1 and I2.

fMRI was used while participants viewed socio-cognitive (social-awareness campaign) videos; study compares drivers with frequent offenses and safe drivers (presumably healthy adult participants). The task probes social cognition (STS reactivity). Satisfies inclusion criteria I1 and I2.
Abstract explicitly identifies the paper as a review. Although it discusses fMRI findings, it is a review article rather than a primary fMRI study, so exclusion criterion E1 applies.

This fMRI study used a faces vs objects viewing paradigm—face perception is a social-related process (Perception/Understanding of Others), meeting I1. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI while participants evaluated personal attributes about themselves (a social cognition/self-processing task), satisfying I1. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract; include for full-text review.

Study investigates birdsong and reports fMRI work in songbirds (non-human). It does not involve human participants (ages 18–65) performing social-related tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 or I2.

Abstract describes brain responses during evaluation of face approachability (a social processing task) but does not specify that functional MRI was used nor participant characteristics (healthy adults, ages 18–65). Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments using a social-empathy visuo-tactile task assessing emotional egocentricity bias in human participants; it also includes behavioral and TMS experiments. Abstract reports an event-related fMRI paradigm using dynamic social vs nonsocial gestures, addressing social processing (meets I1). Abstract reports fMRI in human participants performing collaborative and competitive tasks (social contexts) and examines brain mechanisms of social motivation; likely healthy adult participants. This meets fMRI social-task criterion and includes healthy adults. Not a review.

Abstract reports a social-judgment task and accompanying neural activation in somatosensory, amygdala, hippocampus and prefrontal regions, implying functional neuroimaging in healthy adults. Abstract reports fMRI responses to moral sentiments (guilt) and study of proneness to social/moral emotions in healthy individuals, indicating an fMRI social-related task (I1). Simultaneous fMRI was used while participants engaged in live verbal interaction (social communication), fulfilling social-related task requirement. Participants were pairs of adult female friends (healthy adults), satisfying the healthy adult group criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI while 44 healthy participants made social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) of voices, directly addressing social-related processing (I1). No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social communication/empathy using dynamic video clips and analyzes BOLD responses—meeting I1. This is a task-based fMRI study examining social cognitive processes (empathy, Theory of Mind, self-other differentiation), satisfying I1. Study used fMRI while participants engaged in one-shot prisoner's dilemma decisions examining neural correlates of social cognition (meets I1). Abstract is an overview/narrative that mentions early fMRI studies of social emotions but does not report original methods or participant details (e.g., whether healthy adults aged 18–65 were scanned). Abstract reports an fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs unfamiliar faces (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Abstract examines social decision-making (ultimatum game) and neural networks, but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or report participant ages (18–65). Abstract reports functional MRI during live reciprocal imitation of hand gestures, a social cognitive task. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

This fMRI study measured brain responses while healthy adult participants received interpersonal manual touch from other people—an inherently social stimulus involving perception/processing of others. Abstract reports examination of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in a group of healthy young adults, meeting criterion I2. Abstract reports human fMRI decoding of social familiarity (friends vs acquaintances), meeting I1. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so I2 cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI task (social closeness with photos of friends vs unknown people) assessing social processing and relates neural activity to social network measures in healthy adults — meets criteria for task-based fMRI in social domain and healthy adult participants. fMRI study of social self/other/reflected evaluations (social processing) and includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31) within 18–65. Abstract describes task-based fMRI and healthy participants, meeting both inclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI experiment examining neural responses to a social situation (bystander effect) while participants witness an emergency, satisfying I1. Participants are non-human (dogs, N=12). Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies in healthy adult human participants (age 18–65) performing social-related tasks. The abstract clearly indicates a canine sample, so it does not meet inclusion criteria I1 and I2.

fMRI study where 20 typical (healthy) participants performed a social attribution task (self/other/situation), directly addressing social cognition. Meets I1 (task during fMRI) and I2 (healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment where participants performed a social attribution task (attributing awareness to another), meeting social-processing fMRI criterion. Participants are described as subjects (healthy adults implied); include for full-text if age details needed.

fMRI study of social behavior (Cyberball and modified Dictator Game) addressing social exclusion/punishment/forgiveness — meets social-related task criterion. fMRI was used during a social-related task (anticipatory interpersonal touch comparing human vs fake hand), meeting I1. The abstract implies healthy human participants but does not report ages explicitly; therefore include for full-text review to confirm I2 (age 18–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants performed tasks involving self- and other-referential recollection (social cognition regarding self and others). fMRI measured responses to faces (natural vs bluish) which is social communication/perception (facial cues), satisfying I1. Abstract reports 25 subjects but does not state ages or health status, so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants viewed and processed realistic social interaction videos (empathic/social processing), and the sample comprised healthy young adult males within the adult age range. Thus it meets both I1 and I2.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others (third-person social interaction), satisfying I1. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review.

fMRI study using an ultimatum game examines social fairness processing (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (I2 unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample.

fMRI was conducted while healthy volunteers performed a social interaction/game with various agents, addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not report participant ages; full text needed to confirm age 18–65, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants formed impressions of others (social evaluation/perception of others), meeting the social-related task requirement and participant criteria. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) task — a social cognition paradigm (meets I1). This fMRI study investigates cross-modal recognition of other individuals (social perception/understanding of others) using a voice-face priming task in human participants, satisfying I1. Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion—clearly a social-perception task (I1). The sample is described as ‘humans’ but health status and ages (18–65) are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm I2.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (N=50, young volunteers) labeled briefly presented emotional facial expressions—a social perception/understanding task. This directly meets the review objective and both inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment probing social communication (perceived friend vs computer), examining neural encoding and interregional coupling related to social context. Abstract reports model-driven functional MRI of social tie formation during an economic (public goods) interaction, addressing social processing. The abstract does not specify participant age/health status, so full-text is needed to confirm I2. Include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports neural measurements during social communicative interactions but does not specify fMRI or participant ages/health. Mouse resting-state fMRI study; not conducted in human adults nor involving a social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria I1 (social task in humans) or I2 (healthy human participants 18–65).

The abstract describes an fMRI study of joint attention (a social cognitive task), satisfying I1. Participant health status and ages are not reported in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports dyadic fMRI during eye contact and derives neural bases for reciprocal social interaction, indicating a social-related task using fMRI (meets I1). Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants judged social interactions (a social-related perceptual task), meeting I1. This is an fMRI study of perception of emotions in dynamic crowds (social processing), satisfying I1. The study used fMRI during a game-theoretic deception task, which is a social-related processing paradigm (meets I1). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so I2 cannot be confirmed; include for full-text review. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining attributions about social situations (social cognition). Abstract indicates human participants performing social-related tasks and reports neural activation; likely healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study examining neural regulation of behavioral mimicry in response to social cues (emotional expression and group membership), which fits social processing constructs; abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health but likely healthy adults. Empirical fMRI study of gaze following (social perception/understanding of others) in human participants. Participants are described as healthy adults; task probes social attention and interaction. No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study where participants judged and conceptualized actions; task taps perception/understanding of others and mental-state reasoning, fitting social-related processing (I1). fMRI study using social-emotional stimuli (angry and happy faces) during task performance with healthy adult subjects (N=30). This meets the review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults; abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of 164 healthy adult participants (age range fits 18–65) performing an interactive mentalizing task (Prisoner’s Dilemma), addressing social cognition/attachment. Thus meets I1 (social-related task during fMRI) and I2 (healthy adult sample). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing processing of social reputation (social-related task), satisfying I1. fMRI study of empathy (social processing: perception/understanding of others) in a minimal-group task with 30 healthy adult participants (18–65). It reports task-based BOLD activation during social-related stimuli and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants watched videos of a violent social interaction—this is a social perception/understanding task, satisfying I1. The abstract does not report participants' health status or ages, so I2 is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm.

fMRI study explicitly investigates self-referential and social stimulus processing in humans, meeting I1. Participant health status and ages (18–65) are not specified in the abstract, so I2 cannot be confirmed from the abstract; include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social-related facial emotion (disgust) perception task examining racial prejudice and neural responses; meets social processing domain. Abstract does not state ages but implies adult healthy participants; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study using a valence classification task on agency and communion (social cognition)—meets I1. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages (18–65) so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm I2.

fMRI study examining speech acts (social communication) with participants performing communicative tasks during scanning, meeting social-related task criterion. fMRI study examining processing of social versus nonsocial gestures (a social-related task). Abstract reports correlations with personality traits and does not indicate clinical populations; implies healthy adult participants. Study is empirical (not a review). Meets I1 and I2.
